childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1957-1969

Growing up in the late 1950s and early 1960s meant a world of tactile textures. The smell of Brylcreem and Aqua Velva. The crack of a wooden baseball bat on a summer evening. The weight of a View-Master in hands, clicking through 3D slides of the Grand Canyon or Disneyland. Childhood had a texture that kids today will never know—everything was tactile, local, present.

At five, children watched Captain Kangaroo with Mr. Green Jeans, Romper Room where the teacher looked through her Magic Mirror, and The Mickey Mouse Club before Annette Funicello grew up. By seven, they'd graduated to Lassie, My Friend Flicka, and The Adventures of Rin Tin Tin—shows where animals were more reliable than adults. They had strong opinions about whether Timmy was actually that accident-prone or just dumb. (He was dumb. Obviously.)

Toys were built to last. Lincoln Logs and Erector Sets for construction. Slinky going down the stairs, over and over. Mr. Potato Head with real potato pieces before the plastic body came along. The Hula Hoop craze hit when they were one—by the time they could walk, everyone was twisting their hips. Frisbees flew through every backyard. Play-Doh came in that distinctive yellow can with the smell that never quite left memory.

Saturday mornings meant one thing: cartoons. Children raced downstairs in footie pajamas, poured their own Frosted Flakes or Sugar Pops, and planted themselves in front of the TV. Huckleberry Hound. Quick Draw McGraw. The Flintstones when they were three—the first primetime animated sitcom. Commercials for toys they'd beg for until Christmas.

TV dinners came on metal trays with the turkey, mashed potatoes, and apple cobbler all in their little compartments. Tang sat in the cabinet—the drink the astronauts drank (or so the commercials claimed). Jiffy Pop and watching the foil dome expand on the stovetop like magic. Baseball cards in bicycle spokes to make that motor sound. Genuinely believing the prize in the Cracker Jack box would be worth something.

At six, the world cracked. The principal's voice came over the intercom. Mothers were waiting at the school door. Adults cried in ways children had never seen. They didn't understand collective mourning yet—the way a country's innocence could shatter in a single afternoon. Dallas taught them that lesson before they had words for it.

generational_identity.html:
The Boomer Generation

Baby Boomer. The name sounds almost quaint now—a demographic term that became an identity, then a punchline, then a political faction. This generation is part of the post-WWII explosion of births that reshaped everything from school construction to rock and roll to social security projections. 76 million Americans, give or take. The largest generation in history until Millennials edged past them.

This cohort was six when Kennedy was shot. First grade. November 22, 1963. They probably remember the teacher's face, the static of the intercom, the early dismissal. Adults were crying, and nobody would explain why. Parents hugged them tighter that night. The funeral procession played on every channel. John-John's salute became one of the first images burned into their generational consciousness. This is this generation's defining rupture—the moment that split the American century in two.

This generation spans 1946 to 1964—a range so wide that early Boomers were fighting in Vietnam while late Boomers were still in diapers. Those born in 1957 are dead center of the boom. Old enough to have absorbed the idealism of the early sixties. Young enough to have caught the disillusionment of the late sixties. They got both, in sequence.

The second rupture came in 1968 when they were eleven. Martin Luther King Jr. shot in April. Bobby Kennedy shot in June. Cities burning. The Democratic convention in chaos. The year felt like America was coming apart at the seams, and they were old enough to watch it on the evening news, young enough to not fully understand, but precisely the right age to feel the ground shifting beneath them.

This cohort is sandwiched between the Silent Generation (who remember the Depression and trusted institutions) and Gen X (who grew up in Boomer cultural shadow and never expected stability). They still believe change is possible. They marched, they protested, they voted. They've been doing it for fifty years. At {{AGE_AT_911}}, this cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Whether it worked depends on what metric is used.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year 1957, Elvis released 'Jailhouse Rock' and 'All Shook Up.' Buddy Holly was recording 'Peggy Sue.' Jerry Lee Lewis was scandalizing parents with 'Great Balls of Fire.' Rock and roll wasn't just music—it was generational warfare, and this generation arrived just as the battle was being won.

Pop culture education started with American Bandstand. Dick Clark, clean-cut and eternally young, introducing the hits while Philadelphia teenagers danced in their school clothes. Children learned the Twist, the Mashed Potato, the Watusi from watching that show. They had opinions about who the best dancers were.

At seven, they were watching The Flintstones, the first animated show in primetime—adults pretending to be for kids, or maybe the other way around. At eight, The Beverly Hillbillies and The Jetsons arrived in the same year, one looking backward, one forward. At nine, the Beatles appeared on Ed Sullivan, and every kid they knew was talking about it on Monday morning.

The British Invasion changed everything. At seven, 'I Want to Hold Their Hand' hit the radio. By ten, children could name every Beatle and had strong opinions about whether John or Paul was the real genius. The Rolling Stones provided the alternative—dangerous where the Beatles were charming. They didn't have to choose, but they probably did.

Television of their formative years mixed comfort and chaos. Leave It to Beaver and The Andy Griffith Show showed an America that never quite existed. Bonanza and Gunsmoke dominated Saturday nights—thirty million people watching the same westerns. Then the evening news showed fire hoses in Birmingham, helicopters in Vietnam, protests on campus. Same screen, different channels, different Americas.

At twelve, 2001: A Space Odyssey bent minds about what movies could do. At thirteen, Easy Rider showed the counterculture from a motorcycle seat. At fourteen, Woodstock happened—maybe they went, probably they didn't, but they knew every band that played and wished they'd been there. The Doors, Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin became saints who died too young.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The sound of a rotary phone is burned into memory. That mechanical whir as the dial returned to position, the weight of the handset, the curly cord that never quite reached where someone wanted to sit. this generation was born the same month Sputnik launched—October 1957—and the beeping of that Soviet satellite set the technological agenda for their entire childhood.

At two, they experienced the dawn of the transistor radio. Suddenly music was portable. They could take rock and roll to the beach, to their room, away from parental supervision. The transistor was tiny, the rebellion it enabled was not. By five, they had their own—probably a Christmas present, probably AM only, probably covered in fake leather.

Television was three channels and rabbit ears, adjusted constantly for better reception. They watched in black and white until around age ten, when color sets became affordable. The first time they saw Bonanza in color—the Ponderosa in full autumn foliage—felt like a revelation. Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color suddenly made sense.

Space Race technology defined childhood expectations. Every Mercury, Gemini, and Apollo launch was appointment viewing. They knew astronaut names the way kids today know athletes. At twelve, they watched Neil Armstrong step onto the moon, probably crowded around a TV with family, watching grainy footage and understanding, even then, that they were seeing history.

At fourteen, the first pocket calculators arrived—$400 for basic math. At nineteen, the first personal computers for hobbyists. At twenty-four, the IBM PC. At thirty-two, the World Wide Web. At forty-three, Google. At fifty, the iPhone. This generation went from party lines and operator-assisted calls to video chatting with grandchildren on the other side of the world. No generation spans that kind of technological distance.

this generation is fluent in technologies that no longer exist: typewriters, carbon paper, mimeograph machines, slide rules, phone booths, card catalogs, paper maps. They've learned every platform that came along—sometimes grudgingly, sometimes eagerly—because the alternative was obsolescence. They're not digital natives, but they've survived every digital disruption.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

The year 1957 brought Sputnik—October 4, three weeks after this cohort's birth. Parents heard it on the radio, that beeping signal from space that meant the Soviets were ahead. The Space Race began with their birth year, and it would define their childhood's sense of possibility and anxiety in equal measure.

The civil rights movement happened on their television screen. At three during the Greensboro sit-ins. Five during the Freedom Rides. Six when Bull Connor turned fire hoses on children in Birmingham. Seven when the Civil Rights Act passed. Nine when Watts burned. Eleven when King was murdered. They grew up watching America argue about what equality actually meant.

At six, Dallas. November 22, 1963. The rupture that defines this generation happened while they were in first grade. Here, what matters is that it launched a decade of violence against leaders that would shape their entire understanding of American power.

At seven, the Beatles landed at JFK airport—February 1964. At eleven, King and Bobby Kennedy were killed two months apart, the country convulsing. At twelve, men walked on the moon—July 20, 1969—and for a moment, everything seemed possible. At thirteen, four students were shot at Kent State, and the war came home.

At eighteen, Vietnam ended—the fall of Saigon, helicopters lifting off rooftops, America's first lost war in their lifetime. 58,000 American names on that wall. At twenty-three, Reagan was shot. At thirty-two, the Berlin Wall fell, and the Cold War they'd grown up under just... ended. At {{AGE_AT_911}}, planes hit the towers, and this cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}}. They were old enough to have perspective, to remember how different airports used to be, to understand that something fundamental had broken.

This generation has lived through the Cuban Missile Crisis, Vietnam, Watergate, Iran hostages, AIDS, Gulf War I, Gulf War II, Great Recession, COVID-19, and January 6th. They've watched the American century peak and begin its complicated decline. The arc of their life traces the arc of American power.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

The job market of 1979 offered a challenging entry point. Stagflation, oil shocks, Carter's malaise speech. The economy was genuinely rough. But here's what rough looked like: Entry-level jobs existed. Companies hired people without experience and trained them. A college degree, if someone had one, was a genuine differentiator—only 25% of this generation got one. If they didn't have a degree, union manufacturing jobs still paid enough to buy a house and raise a family.

Career paths looked like this: get hired, prove oneself, get promoted, stay for decades, get a pension, retire. The company wasn't a friend, but there was a social contract. They invested in employees. Employees gave them loyalty. It wasn't perfect, but it was predictable. It was possible to plan a life around it.

This generation climbed the ladder when the ladder was still attached to something. Middle management existed as a destination, not just a waystation. Promotions came with real raises, not just title changes. Their peak earning years—their forties and fifties—coincided with the longest bull market in American history. The Reagan tax cuts. The Clinton boom. The math worked.

Those who went into professions—medicine, law, engineering, accounting—built equity when equity was building. They opened practices when malpractice insurance was affordable. They joined partnerships when partnerships were still partners, not employees of private equity firms. They accumulated credentials when credentials still protected territory.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis hit—and retirement plans evaporated overnight. this generation is now retired or approaching retirement, which is a concept their children view as theoretical. They have Social Security at full benefits. They might have a pension—one of the last Americans who will. The deal they got is the deal that disappeared. They didn't design the system—they just participated in it, followed the rules as they existed, built a life on a foundation that was later demolished for those who followed.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

The generation that came of age when having a crush meant riding a bike past someone's house. When getting their phone number was a victory, even though calling meant talking to their parents first, and the phone was in the kitchen where everyone could hear. When passing notes in class felt dangerously intimate.

This cohort came of age during the sexual revolution, which arrived in stages. The Pill became available when they were three, widely adopted by the time they were sixteen. Premarital sex went from scandal to standard practice during their adolescence. Woodstock happened when they were twelve—'free love' was in the air even if they were too young to participate. By the time they dated seriously, the rules had changed from their parents' generation.

They probably got married younger than their children did. Average age at first marriage in 1980, when they were twenty-three: 22 for women, 25 for men. Today it's 28 and 30. They might have divorced, too—this generation normalized divorce, took the stigma away, made it a genuine option rather than a last resort. Whether that's liberation or loss depends on who this cohort ask and when.

Their relationship with communication technology is genuinely remarkable. They grew up with rotary phones and party lines, where neighbors could listen in. Long-distance calls were expensive—they planned them, kept them short. They wrote letters by hand, waited days for responses. The pace of intimacy was slower, the anticipation longer.

This generation has adapted to every wave: touch-tone phones, answering machines, cordless phones, cell phones, smartphones, texting, video calls. They can write a proper letter and send an emoji. They've probably been frustrated teaching their parents to text and frustrated by their kids' texting habits. They're the bridge generation in communication, fluent in methods that span fifty years.

Their friendships required effort. No social media to maintain passive awareness. If they wanted to know how someone was doing, they called them, visited them, wrote them. Their address book was physical, handwritten, updated with each move and marriage. The friends they've kept for fifty years are friends because they actively chose to keep them, over and over.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

The economic landscape for those entering adulthood was shaped by parents who survived the Depression. They saved obsessively, paid cash for everything, and treated debt like moral failure. They grew victory gardens, reused aluminum foil, kept rubber bands in kitchen drawers 'just in case.' This generation inherited their caution even as the economy encouraged spending.

In 1980, when this cohort was twenty-three, a median home cost $47,200—about 2.5 times the median household income. They bought when buying was possible. They invested in stocks during the longest bull market in history. They accumulated assets while those assets were still on sale.

Credit cards arrived when they were in their twenties—Visa and Mastercard as we know them started in the late '60s and '70s. The idea of buying now and paying later was novel. Their parents would have been horrified. They adapted, using credit strategically while their parents' voices echoed in their heads about living within their means.

Their pension—if they have one—is increasingly rare. Defined benefit plans that guaranteed retirement income have been systematically dismantled since the 1980s, replaced by 401(k)s that shift all risk to workers. They might be among the last Americans to retire with genuine security, a monthly check that arrives regardless of what the stock market does.

This generation has watched the market boom and crash, boom and crash. Black Monday in 1987. The dot-com bubble. The 2008 collapse. Each time, they were told the fundamentals were sound. Each time, they weren't. They learned that the market is a casino with better PR, but they kept playing because mattresses don't compound.

Their biggest financial anxiety now is longevity risk—outliving their savings. They planned for retirement at 65, but they might live to 90. Healthcare costs compound. The math they did at forty doesn't work at seventy. Nobody told them to plan for three decades of not working.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This generation's biggest blind spot is mistaking an exceptional economy for normal circumstances. The post-WWII boom that launched their life wasn't a baseline—it was a historical anomaly. American manufacturing dominance because Europe was rubble. Strong unions because the New Deal was fresh. High taxes on the wealthy because the war required shared sacrifice. Government investment in infrastructure because Eisenhower wanted highways.

That world doesn't exist anymore. But this cohort sometimes gives advice as if it does. 'Just walk in and ask for a job.' 'A firm handshake is what matters.' 'I started in the mailroom and worked my way up.' These strategies worked when companies trained people, when there were mailrooms, when showing up was half the battle. The disconnect frustrates younger people who've sent 200 applications into the digital void.

This generation adapted so successfully to change that they underestimate how hard adaptation is. They learned new technologies, new management styles, new workplace norms. Each time, they figured it out. But they also had stable employment while learning. Try learning new skills while working two gig jobs without health insurance. The runway they had doesn't exist.

There's a tendency to see systemic problems as individual failures. If younger generations can't afford houses, they must be spending frivolously. If they're anxious, they need to toughen up. If they're drowning in student debt, they should have chosen better majors. The possibility that the system changed, that the math no longer works, is hard to accept when the math worked so well for them.

This generation struggled with racial reckoning. They grew up in segregated spaces even when segregation was technically illegal—redlined neighborhoods, tracked schools, 'good areas' that meant white areas. The progress they witnessed—civil rights laws, integration, a Black president—can make it seem like the work is done. It isn't. The systems became subtler, not smaller.

The climate crisis is another blind spot. This generation built the carbon-intensive economy and enjoyed its benefits. The worst consequences will arrive after they're gone. When younger people express climate grief, it can seem hyperbolic. When they demand systemic change, it can seem impractical. But they'll live with the floods and fires and famines. This generation mostly won't.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

20s (1977-1987): The typical trajectory for someone born in 1957 meant entering adulthood during stagflation, disco, and gas lines. The economy was rough—double-digit inflation, double-digit unemployment. But jobs existed. They probably married younger than their children would, bought their first car, maybe their first house. The Iranian hostage crisis played on the nightly news for 444 days. Reagan arrived promising morning in America, and by their late twenties, the economy was booming. They started building.

30s (1987-1997): This was their construction decade. Career advancement, family formation, asset accumulation. The Berlin Wall fell when they were thirty-two, and the Cold War they'd grown up under just... ended. The Soviet Union dissolved. History was supposedly over—liberal democracy had won. If they invested in stocks, they made money. If they bought real estate, they made more. Everything they'd been taught about hard work and reward seemed to be proving true.

40s (1997-2007): Peak earning years. Peak responsibility. Their kids were teenagers, which was its own war zone. The internet arrived and changed everything, but they were established enough to adapt without starting over. The dot-com bubble inflated and burst—maybe they lost paper gains, probably nothing permanent. They were forty-four on 9/11, old enough to process it, young enough to live with the long aftermath of two new wars.

50s (2007-2017): The Great Recession hit when they were fifty-one. If their house was their retirement plan, they watched it lose forty percent of its value. If they were planning early retirement, those plans got postponed. Recovery came, but it came slowly, unevenly. They started thinking seriously about how many working years remained, about whether Social Security would still be there, about what retirement actually meant.

60s (2017-2027): They're here now, or just past it. Retirement is happening or already happened. Health is increasingly front of mind—they're watching friends deal with cancer, heart disease, diabetes, cognitive decline. COVID hit their age group harder than most. They've become expert at Zoom calls with grandchildren. They're thinking about legacy, about what they'll leave behind, about how to be useful in their remaining years.

70s and beyond (2027+): The actuarial tables say they have one to two decades if they've made it this far. They'll watch grandchildren navigate a world increasingly foreign to their experience—climate changed, AI ascendant, democracy uncertain. They'll tell stories about rotary phones and Sputnik and JFK that will seem like science fiction. The challenge is staying engaged, staying relevant, staying connected across a generational chasm that widens every year.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

4.3 million people were born in the US the same year—1957 was peak baby boom, the demographic tsunami at full height. A cohort so large it bent every institution it passed through: schools in the '60s, colleges in the '70s, workplaces in the '80s, and now healthcare and Social Security systems adapting to their needs.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945): They came of age during the Depression and WWII. They learned to conform, to trust institutions, to defer gratification. Boomers learned to question everything. The Silent Generation stayed married; Boomers normalized divorce. The Silent Generation trusted authorities; Boomers protested them. The Silent Generation built stable careers at single companies; Boomers job-hopped and called it liberation. The Silent Generation thinks Boomers were spoiled. Boomers think the Silent Generation was repressed. They're both right.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): They grew up in Boomer shadow, the forgotten middle children. They were latchkey kids while Boomers were protesting Vietnam. They entered the workforce during recessions while Boomers were consolidating gains. They're more cynical because they had to be—the safety net Boomers relied on was already fraying by the time they needed it. They don't expect pensions or Social Security. They've been preparing for collapse their whole lives.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): The wealth gap is staggering. At their age, Boomers controlled 21% of national wealth. Millennials control 7%. Boomers bought houses for three years' salary; Millennials face eight to ten years' salary. Boomers graduated into opportunity; Millennials graduated into the Great Recession. They have the same degrees, the same work ethic, radically different outcomes. When they seem bitter, there's math behind it.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): They're visitors from different planets. Gen Z has never known a world without internet, smartphones, school shootings, or climate anxiety. Boomer formative experiences—moon landing, Watergate, Vietnam—are as distant to Gen Z as WWI was to Boomers. Boomers grew up with three TV channels and mandatory family dinners. Gen Z grew up with infinite content, algorithmically served, in bedrooms with screens instead of windows.

This generation controls 52% of American wealth while comprising 21% of the population. Their life expectancy at birth was about 69 years. Thanks to medical advances and relative prosperity, they're likely to live into their eighties if they've made it this far. This generation is healthier and more politically powerful at this age than any before. What they do with that power—the votes they cast, the policies they support—will shape the world their grandchildren inherit long after they're gone.
